title: Get on with it!
intro: From watching cat videos on YouTube to searching your own name online... people do all sorts of things in order to delay doing the tasks we really should be doing. Rob and Alice discuss why it can be difficult to get on with things.
this_week_question: Which American politician said: "You may delay, but time will not?" Was it …
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: delaying doing something you're supposed to do
something that is more important than other things
doing two activities together: one you should do but are avoiding, and one that you love doing but isn't productive

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: …and I'm Rob.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: So Rob, did you get that research done that I asked you to do over the weekend?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh … It was at the top of my to-do list. But Sunday night came around so quickly, and I just – you know – I didn't get round to it.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Rob! If I'd known you weren't going to do the research, I'd have done it myself. What did you actually do at the weekend, anyway?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh, you know, this and that. It's funny how time slips by without you noticing.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hmm, yes. I bet you spent the whole weekend watching cat videos on YouTube – and googling your own name.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: What? That's unfair and untrue, Alice – well, mostly untrue, anyway – I did some shopping and I fixed my bike as well as watching videos and googling myself.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, perhaps I should say at this point that today's show is about procrastination , which means not doing something you're supposed to do.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, I do feel bad about my procrastination actually.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, that's good to hear. But let's move on now and hear today's quiz question: Can you tell me which American said: 'You may delay, but time will not?' Was it…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. I think I'll go for a) John F Kennedy because I reckon he was good at making to-do lists and then getting on with them.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Unlike somebody I could mention.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Alice, I thought we were going to move on?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Alright then.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Personally, I think it's important to try and understand why we procrastinate. So let's hear from Daphna Oyserman, Professor of Psychology, Communication and Education at the University of Southern California, talking about this.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Daphna Oyserman, Professor of Psychology, Communication and Education at the University of Southern California People spend most of their time focussed on the present, which makes perfect sense because the present is now, and for sure. Unfortunately, many things that are quite important about the future require that we start doing things now rather than waiting for later to happen. Things like saving for retirement, studying for college entry exams, revising papers, preparing for work reports. Unfortunately, waiting till later means that we won't have much time.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: So, we are too focussed on the present, and reluctant to engage in tasks that relate to the future. Why's that, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, like Professor Oyserman says, things in the future may never happen – or seem too far off for you to take seriously. For example, when you're young, sorting out a pension plan doesn't feel like a priority – or something that's more important than other things.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: But according to a new study, if you think about time in smaller units – so days, for example, rather than months or years – you are likely to start a task more quickly.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So, this weekend I wasted two days…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Or 2,880 minutes.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That does sound more urgent, when you put it like that.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. And you need to minimize – or reduce – distractions. Turn off your tech and knuckle down to your tasks, Rob.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: To knuckle down , by the way, means to start working hard. But Alice, sometimes it's hard to knuckle down to a task when you don't know how to start it – or you're scared to start it – or sometimes just because you know it's going to be really tedious – and that means boring.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. So what's your excuse, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, it's boredom, usually.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: You should try temptation bundling.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Temptation bundling - what's that?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Temptation bundling means doing two activities together – one you should do but are avoiding, and one you love doing which isn't productive.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: For example, eating biscuits while I work?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, that's right. That sounds like a good one for you, Rob.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: It might be a good idea actually. Well, let's listen to Dr Catherine Loveday talking about how we often underestimate how long things will take us.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Catherine Loveday, Westminster University There's this thing called the planning fallacy. My favourite one is always the example of the Oxford English Dictionary that they started in 1857 and it was supposed to take five years, but five years later they'd only got to the word 'ant'. In the end it took another 70 years and then it was out of date and they had to start again anyway. We never seem to get any better at judging time in the future and how long things will take us.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That's Dr Catherine Loveday. So what's a fallacy , Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It's a mistaken belief or idea.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And for the famous Oxford English Dictionary – their mistake was to think they would get the work done in five years when it actually took 70!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Gosh! Wow! What a long time! And talking about time – ours is running out – let's go back to today's question. I asked: Which American said, "You may delay, but time will not?" Was it … a) John F Kennedy, b) Benjamin Franklin or c) Franklin Roosevelt?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I very confidently said John F Kennedy.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, you did. And you were wrong today Rob, I'm afraid. It was Benjamin Franklin, one of the Founding Fathers of the United States. Franklin was a leading author, printer, political theorist, politician, freemason, postmaster, scientist, inventor, civic activist, statesman, and diplomat. I doubt he wasted much waste time procrastinating!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: No. OK, without further delay, here are the words we learned today: procrastination priority minimize knuckle down tedious temptation bundling fallacy

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon!

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
